Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Financial Ethics in the Context of Institutions and Legislation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The financial crisis of 2008 resulted in significant financial realignments globally. These have included both thoroughgoing legislative reforms and specific banking sector reorganizations. Now, a decade later, the research supported by this award asks an important question: how have these changes affected the day-to-day practices and values of those working in finance? Unlike most research on finance, this ethnographic project is focused on the local and the micro-processes through which global change must occur. This is a critically important and often missing perspective. In some locales the banking crisis has persisted. Understanding the motivations and activities of those who actually practice finance is a key part of identifying the underpinnings of financial resilience and avoiding future crises.

The research will be conducted by Yale University anthropology doctoral student, Theodore Park, with the guidance of Dr. Paul Kockelman. The researcher has chosen to conduct the research in northern Italy because it is one site where the financial crisis has continued, despite targeted legislation, and because Italian reforms are sometimes identified as potential models for reforms in the United States. The researcher will collect data with a comparative research design, focusing on two wealth management firms, one of which has chosen to adopt the reforms and become publicly traded, and one of which has chosen to sustain its earlier identity as a local, private institution. The researcher will focus on the effects of variable institutional structures; the impacts of legislation, particularly the European Union's Markets in Financial Instruments Directive; and variation in ethical discourse and practices. Study populations will include wealth managers, fund managers, support staff, clients, and family members. Data will be collected through a mix of ethnographic methods including participant observations, semi-structured interviews, life history mappings, surveys, and focus groups. These data will be supplemented with archival research; compilations of relevant legislation; and analyses of media, including manager training materials and social media. Findings from this research will be shared with policy makers, the institutions studied, and the general public. The research also will contribute to improved theory of the social science of financial institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project began as an attempt to understand how the people who manage the money of the middle class and wealthy think about their work. Do they see what they are doing as morally good? And what are the conditions for it being so? The project provides answers to these in the specific context of Brescia, in Northern Italy, as the result of ethnographic research amongst wealth managers and their clients at several different financial institutions in the city. On the one hand, the findings show the local and national contours of these kinds of reflections. The wealth managers studied saw themselves as responsible for educating savers, shielding them from the losses that had been suffered by the previous generation of Italian savers who had invested exclusively in government bonds, by diversifying their portfolios. On the other hand, the findings suggested that these evaluations of their conduct were linked to how their bank or financial institution was structured. The more direct their contact with the client the more they expressed their role and its value in terms of teaching others to deal with and behave appropriately with risk. They evaluated the moral worth of their wealth primarily in the context of the relationships they had with their clients. These findings also suggest some of the ways in which financial practices are local and particular rather than universal or neutral. The longer reflections that come out of this project outline in greater detail the relationship of wealth managers and their clients, and the kind of moral system it generates (and what this ignores). This offers the opportunity for renewed debate on financial reform with an attention to how individuals behave and what changes their behavior.

 

The project also became the opportunity for a wider ethnographic study of crisis. Despite being one of the wealthiest and largest industrial areas in Europe, Brescia is also the site of a series of rapid social changes. Increasing immigration since the 90s has changed the shape of the industrial workforce and the city itself. The same period of time has seen drastic changes to the role of marriage and religion within contemporary northern Italian society. Un and under employment have become widespread, despite the relative wealth of the city, especially amongst the young. These kinds of social changes are also tied to the onset of various economic and financial crises, and emerged in the context of discussions with savers and their relatives in the city. Although the particulars of the situation are specific to Italy’s historical circumstances, parallels can be found in contemporary American society, exacerbated by the pandemic. If the most profound consequence of prolonged economic stagnation and crisis in Italy has been the continuing economic dependence of the young, it is notable that throughout the crisis a similar situation has emerged in America.
